segments.text: This is September 29, 1981.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is an interview with General Ludeke in College Station, testing.
Let's start in now.
This is an interview with Major General Ludeke.
Today is the 29th of September, 1981.
Let's start with your early life.
You were born the 1st of October, 1910, in El Dorado, Texas.
And could you, let's start by talking about your parents.
Could you tell me about your heritage, your background, where your parents came from?
My father's father, my grandfather, was born in New Orleans off parents who had immigrated from Germany.
And he married a
girl whose parents had immigrated at approximately the same time from Czechoslovakia.
And they came to by way of several places that I'm not familiar with in New Orleans and ended up in East Texas at Lockhart.
And it was there that my father was born.
And he moved when he was approximately 14 out to Stanford, Texas, and when he was approximately 17 down to El Dorado.
And it was there that he married my mother, Lizzie Octavia Smith.
whose father and mother came to Texas from Tennessee and settled mainly in Coke County.
My mother and father met in San Angelo, or near San Angelo, and were married in El Dorado in 1909.
And then I was born five miles from El Dorado in 1910.
Could you tell me about their education?
Their education was limited to the sixth and seventh grades and they had no further formal education than that.
What did your father do?
What type of occupation?
My father was a stockman farmer.
He would have loved to have been a big rancher, except he didn't have the resources to become one.
And so he had to satisfy himself by participating in ranching with other people and by operating a stock farm.
So in addition to peripheral type of ranching, we raised cotton feed and worked the farm as farms were operated in those days with no machinery.
So the principal staple crop was cotton, although we raised
Cattle, horses, mules, hogs, other things that it took to provide food and try to provide enough money to keep the family together.
And how many were in the family?
I was the oldest of eight.
No kidding, eight?
Eight, the youngest having been born while I was a freshman here at A&M.
No kidding.
That's quite a spread of about 20 years.
Yes it is.
All of those except one are still in fine shape and living and have their own families and going about their own business.
When you say he was a stockman farmer, what exactly does that mean?
Was he a tenant farmer then?
Well, he was a tenant part of the time, although most of my life he owned his own place.
When I say stockman farmer, I mean by that that you have a place where you have a farm and you have the stock necessary to work the farmers, horses, mules, and so forth.
And you have some cattle, sheep, or other animals that you're raising, trying to make money by having.
Like a stock farm, you could, I don't associate a stock farm with selling farm products.
I associate that with selling stock.
that you have kept by the products from the farm, the feed and things of this nature.
So this was both.
He raised feed for livestock and fed livestock and sold the livestock, but he also raised cotton and wheat and other products that were sold directly as such.
And how many acres did he have?
Well, it varied from...
640 square miles down to as low as 240.
The last place that he owned of his own was 240 acres.
And did he use tenant farmers, too, for the cotton?
No, he did his own.
He did his own what?
He and I and the rest of the kids
We all worked on the farm.
So he didn't use either tenants nor migrants?
No.
Well, in the earlier days, for picking cotton, he used migrants.
Pickers, all right.
But other than that, no, he didn't use them.
Later, of course, machines took the place of even cotton pickers.
But he used them during the time, at least, that I was involved.
What kind of person was he?
Can you tell me about his character?
Yes, I certainly can.
My dad was, of course, a wonderful man like other people's dads.
He was quite young as compared to me as a father, because he was not quite 19 when I was born.
And so in a sense, I grew up with him.
But he was a rather large man, 5'10", 180 or 190 pounds.
A very physically strong man.
And also, in a stubborn German way, a very strong-minded.
Strong-willed?
A strong-willed man.

And so as a kid growing up and trying to learn how to live in the world, I had some problems living with him because he was very much a perfectionist with German stubbornness, and he expected out of me a great deal.
And I tried real hard to
to make it.
I'm not sure whether I finally did or not.
Was he an authoritarian type?
I'm sorry?
Authoritarian?
Was he very authoritarian?
Yes, quite.
And stern?
Very, yes.
I don't mean by that that he was a crank or anything.
He was a lot of fun and enjoyed it and enjoyed participating in all kinds of fun things.
But he was very, very stern and worked to establish principles that were fully enunciated.
There wasn't any question about it.
He expected to, and did, live by them.
He expected his family to live by them.
He expected other people that he associated with to live by them, otherwise he didn't associate with them.
Now, was he the authority in the family or in the household, or was your mother?
He was.
Well, I have to moderate that a bit.
They were in their respective areas, but overall there was no question about that.
No.
Can you tell me about your mother?
Yes.
My mother was a wonderful person.
She was the youngest of five children
in her father's first family, but he was married again and had seven more children, so she was really one of twelve children.
And really in the middle, because she was the last of the first group and was raised
by her older sister.
There was no mother at that time.
And they were a very poor family and poor in an economic sense.
And her father was very much of an entrepreneur, very jack of all trades and not particularly good at any of them.
And he hauled his family around over West Texas.
and in one way or another established three or four towns.
There may be some question in other people's minds about whether they established them or not, but Pontotoc and Kickapoo and
Caffer, I think, certainly established those.
He usually would find a way to be the postmaster, and run a store, and maybe build a church.
So he worked on in that way.
And the last place he lived was the town he established.
Town, unquote.
just west of El Dorado, between El Dorado and Ozona, called Caffer.
And he lived there until he died at about 86 or something about like that.
The mother didn't get the education that she wanted to get.
There was no way to do it.
And when she married dad, she was 19.
And so thereafter, of course, she led the same life that he did and the one I just talked about.
But she was a very compassionate woman, a very great amount of common sense.
and understanding of human nature.
And in the situation she was in, she needed it all.
With that many children and those kind of economic straits, why, it wasn't an easy life.
Was religion important in your family?
Yes, religion was important, although we didn't
attend church regularly and didn't make too much of a fuss about it.
We lived pretty carefully under the religious principles, and we actually were members of the Baptist church.
and attended when we could.
Most of the children were baptized in that.
Some of them went to other churches later on.
But we were very religious in what I think is a true religious sense in accepting the principles and the teachings of the Bible and following them.
We didn't make a lot of public fuss about the thing or become big pillars in the church at the time.
Economically we couldn't afford it, among other things, but it wasn't their nature anyway.
I was wondering if your father ever took a position of leadership in the community.
He did in the ways that he could.
He was a member of the school board two or three times, two or three different school boards that we used when we had small school districts.
And later the county, when it was all converted to county, he was there.
He helped the sheriff a number of times, on special occasions as deputy, or when there was need, not as an occupation.
And he was very active in all the elections, and local, not national.
as anybody else, I guess, in the National, but I mean, his work was mostly for local county offices.
He never ran for election himself?
Oh, he ran one time for sheriff, and was defeated.
But that was quite late in his life.
But other than that one time he never did know him and he never held public office.
How did you get along with all your brothers and sisters?
Fine.
They considered it more how did they get along with me because I was the oldest.
Very, very well indeed.
living the kind of life we did, why it was necessary that I look after them, physically look after them.
We had to ride horseback to school five miles from back every day, for example, and the two just younger than I am are girls.
And at the time my brother, who was still younger than that, was big enough
take on those kind of jobs, why the situation was different and I was gone.
So I had a great deal of, had to accept a great deal of responsibility for them, which I did.
And they understood it, appreciated it, and it's been that way, so we've had no problem.
You've had a very successful career, rising to major general.
I was wondering in what way do you think that your parents are responsible for that?
My parents are, as far as I'm concerned, directly responsible for it in several ways.
One of those was their convictions and the strength of their convictions.
They felt if something was right, they didn't have to have anything else to recommend it.
That was enough by itself.
They also felt that if you really wanted to do something that was right, and you wanted to do it good enough, you could find a way to do it.
And yet they were not
disposed to a reckless approach to that end, and certainly not to a dishonest one to that end.
They also felt that of anything, I think when I was a kid it was probably most important to me

that they taught that any time I had an opportunity to learn something that I didn't know, it was worth learning, whether I thought I needed it or not, or whether I thought I would ever use it or not.
And I followed that.
Sometimes it wasn't too easy.
And I swear, in retrospect, I don't think I ever learned anything that some way I didn't use in a very relatively short time after that, and was tickled to death that I knew it.
So I think that was an important thing.
But mainly it was the knowledge of their desire that we do well and do it right.
that provided the motivation and the drive and the stickability to get something done.
Both of them.
Let's move to your education.
Can you tell me about your early education?
Early education, I guess first grade is the earliest that I went to a little school in Slacker County called Bailey Ranch.
And it was a little school with one teacher.
There were eleven or twelve, I've forgotten which, students or kids.
And they ranged from the first grade to the tenth grade.
In my class in the first grade there was one other boy, one other student who was a boy.

And I don't know how that teacher did it, but she kept us quite busy from the time we got to school until we left to go home, and still taught ten other classes in the same room, all in the same room.
And we didn't find any time on our hands or any boredom or anything else.
We were busy and working and learning.
And I think we learned as much as first graders anywhere else did, at least we certainly held our own after that.
Well, I went to that school for two years, and in the meantime they had built another school, same group, same district, same purpose, but it was a bigger, nicer school with better facilities.
And so I went to that one a year and a half, and then we moved so that I went to the school in town, in El Dorado.
for the rest of my grade school and high school education, which would have been the fifth on through the eleventh.
Until you graduated in 1928.
Now what were your favorite subjects while you were in school?
Well, I guess if I have to...
categorize them that way.
I would have to say that history was my favorite subject.

I got the problem though because I couldn't find any way when I was about the ninth or tenth grade that I could ever make a living making a difference how much I know about history in that particular country.
That is a problem.
I'd better concentrate a little more on things other than history.
So I felt real comfortable with mathematics and science projects, and so I took all of those in high school that I could.
And when I came to A&M, I took chemical engineering.
What type of student were you?
In high school?
Well, I was about varied from one to four in the class, I guess, at the top of the class.
So you were a hard worker?
Well, yes, I was pretty hard, but that period of time, those four years that I was in high
was also a very, very difficult period for us economically as a family.
A lot of times I'd get home from school by hurrying around 4 or 4.30
I'd go down and relieve Dad on the tractor in the field and plow until 11 or 12 o'clock.
He'd come back and take over for me and I'd go home and do my studying after that.
And a good many times I'd run that right on up until it was time to go back to school and just go back to school.
That wasn't an everyday occurrence, but it was certainly more than every week for quite a while.
And it kept my grades from being quite as good, I think, as they would have been.
On the other hand, it sure as hell kept me out of trouble, too.
You didn't have time for any sports or activities, or did you?
Some, but not very many.
I mean, not in the sense that kids think of it now at all, not anything like that.
So you didn't have an opportunity to be in any groups or clubs or organizations?
Not in high school.
I played basketball.
I don't remember that there were any clubs at that time.
Most other kids were in the same boat that I was.
Did you consider yourself well liked or popular in high school?
In school you mean?
Yes.
Not to set the world on fire or anything, but I think people didn't dislike me.
They admired some of my qualities, and when they were in trouble, they looked to me to help them out.
So, I wasn't the high school hero or anything like that.
When you graduated from high school,
Did you have firm ideas of what you wanted to do, or were you still sort of up in the air, or what did you think?
Well, if you had asked me then, I would have said I had firm ideas of what I wanted to do.
But I don't honestly think, in retrospect, that anybody at that age and in that circumstances really knows as much as he thinks he knows about what he wants to do.
On the other hand, I feel it's good that they feel that way.
At least they're getting started doing something.
It doesn't leave you in this category of, I've heard a lot about recently, of having to go find yourself, which is about as ridiculous as anything I can think of, offhand.
So I thought, yes, I came down here to A&M for a short course in the summer.
used that as a means of checking into the school and what it did.
They were offering this new course in chemical engineering and everybody said that was the hardest course they had in this place.
So I thought that's what I'd like to try because the oil companies were just really getting to the point where they were needing that kind of help.
You could get a job if it got through.
So when you graduated from high school, then you had made up your mind that you wanted to be an engineer.
Yes.
Now, when you thought about being an engineer, did you think of any other school besides A&M?
Yes, I thought of several, particularly Texas University.
But after I came down here in the summer, between the time I graduated, I didn't try to think about anything else then, because I didn't think there were any that held a candle to it.
I think we have to remember that at that time, your knowledge of what this university did or that university did was very much limited by comparison to what it is now.
The school might enjoy a fine reputation in this or that, but there would be a certainly limited number of people who knew that.
somewhere in West Texas where there wasn't much communication.
And if we remember, radio had only been available to homes a matter of five or six years before that.
It was fine to people that didn't know very much about it.
So one had to go and look up the facts himself, if you could find them, make up your own mind about it.
And that's what the trip down here did for me.
Now, the fact that A&M was a military institution, did that have any bearing whatsoever on going to that school?
Well, I wasn't particularly anxious to be military at that point.
Had you ever had any contact with the military before?
No.
No, not at all.
Well, I had an uncle who fought in World War II, and I heard all his stories and whatnot, but other than that, no.
World War I. I'm sorry, World War I, yeah.
But other than that, I hadn't.
And I didn't have any wild desire about it.
So you never thought about getting an engineering degree at West Point or a service academy?
No, not at that time, no.
But to come to NL, well, of course, you couldn't come here without being in the Corps.
Sure, right.
But even if you could, I wouldn't have done it because I couldn't see anybody passing up a wonderful opportunity like that.
So I would have been in the Corps in any case.
So you arrived in the summer of 1928?
Yeah, September.
Well, you took a short course first in the summer.
Well, that was only, that's a farmer's thing.
That's three days, I think.
Oh, I see.
I don't consider, that just afforded me an opportunity to be here and to check into some things.
One of the things that afforded me the opportunity to do was contact a couple of people
who were here who could give me a job if I came down here.
And I did contact them, and they indicated that maybe they could.
They didn't have anything right.
They couldn't say absolutely they will, but they would try.
Well, of course, that brings me to the next question.
Your family was basically poor.
How could you afford to go to college?
I borrowed from my uncle.
and who also lived there in El Dorado, and who was sheriff there for sixteen years.
And he was a bachelor, didn't have sons of his own.
So he loaned me some money and gave me some money.
It went along, and then when I got here, I worked for them.
My senior year, when I was here, I was
my jobs were good enough that I was able to go to school and more than make my way.
And then in the years following school I paid back the money that I had borrowed earlier.
Now what type of jobs did you have while you were there?
Well I was here, well the first year
I mostly worked with the building grounds people, which translates into pushing a real-type lawn mower for 25 cents an hour.
I did some work in the power plant.
Most of that translates to shoveling coal, but there was some other work in there, and most of that late at night.
during my freshman year, and of course I didn't get rich doing that either.

I had worked a little bit in the student post office and a little bit in the faculty post office, just when they needed extra help in both cases, and a little bit in the fiscal department during my freshman year.
Again, that odd time not to study things.
So when I came back as a sophomore, I got that job in the fiscal department, which started I think at seven o'clock in the evening, and I usually get through by 9.30 or 10, sometimes 11.
So I had two to three hours of work in the fiscal department.
And I got more work in the student post office, about half time in there then.
And then the next year, while both of these jobs were increasing, I was the student postmaster and handled the whole thing for the last two years.
So by that time you were in a fairly decent financial situation?
Doing reasonably well, of course.
The people looking at the money that you get
No.
You said before that your dad ran for sheriff and he was a little bit interested in politics.
He was a Democrat like everybody was in Texas at the time.
Yeah, he was a Democrat.
Let's talk a little bit about his and then
philosophy or political philosophy?
Were you moderates, liberals, conservatives?
What did you consider yourself?
I think we have to temper almost anything with a recognition of the communication situation back in those days.
I think one could say liberal or conservative and it really wouldn't
measure one's philosophy then.
My dad was just a straight Democrat.
He had no room for the Republicans or anybody else for that matter.
But the issues were
so different.
I don't know what he would be if he were alive today.
Well, what did he feel about prohibition?
He thought that it would be a good idea if he could make it, as a practical matter, make it go, but he didn't think he could.
And so he was against it.
I mean, he was for leaving things alone, not for the amendment.
What did you think about Franklin Roosevelt and the New Deal?
Well, at that time I was gone, and since that was the height of the Depression I was kind of busy, I'll tell you for sure.
So, I really don't know.
I just don't know.
He was very bitter about Hoover, but I don't know whether that was just because Hoover was a Republican or because
he really had a different kind of judgment on the economic situation.
Did your father ever, do you know, even though you were gone, did your father ever accepted any government aid during the New Deal?
No, absolutely not.
He didn't go for that talk, not any, in any form.
He considered accepting aid as a damned insult to his capabilities to make a living for himself and his family.
He wouldn't have accepted one if he had been starving to death.
Now, what about your political philosophy?
Well, I grew up there as a Democrat.
As a matter of fact, when you mentioned that, I was thinking about a time when I was a little kid when there was a Republican president elected, and I've forgotten which one right now.
But he threw out the postmaster.
who was a Democrat, and appointed a new postmaster, whom I heard my dad say was a goddamn Republican.
And he was talking to a neighbor about this damn Republican up there as a postmaster.
So we were going to go to town in a few days, and I went with him once to the post office, because I wanted to see this, this Republican.
So we, I went to the post office with my father, and he knew the man of course, I didn't.
And he spoke to him, called him Stratkins, and we talked for quite a little while there, and we got out of the post office, I said, so I think he was a pretty nice man.
Dad said, well he's a fine man if he just wasn't a damn Republican.
But I had never seen one, I don't know what the hell a Republican looked like, you see.
I was very surprised that they were human and everything was fine.
I continued to be a Democrat on up until 10 or 12 years ago.
And now you're a Republican?
Yes.
When they come out with the likes of McGovern as a candidate for president of the United States, I can't stomach that in any sense.
And what did you think about Lyndon Johnson as far as his programs?
Well, about his program, I don't, I didn't like it.
I knew Lyndon Johnson
pretty well.
Had a good many occasions to do business with him, government business.
And I have to admire a great many things about him.
But there's some things that I don't admire about him, didn't admire about him.
I think he understood an awful lot better what made Lyndon Johnson move
than he did what made the United States move on a long-term basis.

I think things that were important to Lyndon Johnson were a little more important to him sometimes than the good of his country, and I don't admire that on anybody, no matter how expedient it might be for the problem at hand.
In other words, ever since McGovern in 1972, you voted, you've been a Republican.
You betcha.
And are you a member of the Republican Party?
Did you ever get active in politics?
Oh, yes.
I'm a member of the Republican National Committee.
I haven't been active in local politics, but reasonably active in national politics.
that actually split ticket in a local sense, because the Republicans haven't put up the best candidates in some of these places.
And when I can have a guy like Tiger Teague, who's a classmate of mine, and I suppose everybody knows what he did and what he stood for,
Well, I'm going to arrange it so that I can vote for him.
I guess never anybody.
OK. Let's go back to A&M, then.
Can you tell me, we talked about your employment there.
Can you tell me about where you lived on campus for your four years?
How were the accommodations?
Well, I think in general, one would say that what we thought were very good accommodations then would be absolutely unacceptable.
to the kids now, and I can't tell you whether this is good or bad, but I have my own notion about it.
When I entered school and entered the Corps, I was assigned a D Battery or Field Artillery, which was the newest unit organized that year.
And that battery was quartered in Foster Hall.
So I spent that year, freshman year, and sophomore year in Foster Hall.
And then the junior year, we moved over and were in Puryear Hall, which was brand new, just opened that year.
and also a senior year.
I was in first year hall.
So the accommodations were pretty good for the time.
They were wonderful as far as I'm concerned for the time.
At that time there still were Hollywood, the huts and all of that, and I had a lot of friends that lived in them, spent a lot of time down there, and they weren't too bad either.
didn't like very much, but they were all right.
What was your opinion of hazing?
Well, I thought it was wonderful actually.
I realize how it sounds to say that, but I think it made people out of an awful lot of
of individuals who might not otherwise have achieved that status.
Well, what do you mean by that?
Could you continue?
I mean, I think it made for a deeper understanding of many kinds of values, including human values.

And it created an understanding of discipline, not just discipline in a military sense, but discipline of thinking and discipline of conduct that kids growing up don't have automatically and now in most cases don't get.
And I think it was good in that sense.
It's true, I'm sure, that it can be abused.
It was abused and has been since.
But I'm also quite convinced that it isn't abused one-fifth as much as people would have you believe it was abused.
Because the thing was handled in such way within the Corps when I was going up in it
that if somebody, someone abused it very much, they were called on the carpet too, and they didn't get by with it.
Little fringe areas, yeah, but I don't think they ever hurt anybody.
How far could it go?
Obviously it has to be some limits on it.
Sure.
Obviously also it had gone a little too far sometimes.
I guess it was at about its height when I was here.
I don't mean because I was here, but in looking at the situation it looked like it kind of peaked right along in those years and obviously it isn't anything like that now.
No, not at all.

So, while I can't deny that I was mighty, mighty happy when Fish Day came, I can also say that I enjoyed every weapon I ever got, except one or two, in which I thought things were abused, and I got lots of them.
Well, were you sorry later on when they decreased the amount of hazing?
I mean, there's almost no hazing at A&M in a physical sense, except for some push-ups, etc.
In a physical sense, there's essentially none, that's right.
Yes.
Do you think that they should have continued the board?
No.
I was a member of the Century Council, and of course this question received quite a lot of consideration.
And I had to vote for it going like it is going.
In other words, decreasing hands.
Decreasing, physically.
Not because it was bad, but because you can't get something as big as the school was visualized to be on the course as it is.
And have these kind of things going on in a routine way, because it's very bigness
kills its effectiveness and breeds abuse.
At the time that I was talking about that I was here, there were, I believe, five students on the campus who were not in the
